channel.title: Build questions
channel.description:
I've been playing around with a build that I'd like to get, but I'm looking for improvement suggestions. Firstly, here's the build: [img]http://img804.imageshack.us/img804/3699/currentbuild.png[/img]
For starters, I was reading the 'post your build' thread here and Niall's Antec 900 was really dusty. I don't want to have to worry about dust and was under the impression that a combination of air filters and positive air pressure would keep it dust-free. Am I right, or will it still get ridiculously dirty? Any other cases that are around that price but better in some way?
Thoughts on the rest? Current price is $1142, plus postage.
I want to set up dual booting with Windows 7 and either FreeBSD or a linux distro, with one OS on each disk. I want to use full disk encryption for the BSD/linux install. The Win7 install is purely for university work that revolves around developing stuff in Visual Studio etc at this stage, but I want the option to upgrade the GPU down the track for gaming if I choose to.
Thanks for the feedback guys.

item.title: Build questions
item.dc:creator: @Budda Budda
item.description:
@Budda wrote:

[quote=“Lothy, post:27, topic:407430”][quote author=Budda link=topic=508716.msg3696046#msg3696046 date=1312428536]

Might be able to start ripping the DVDs I rent and actually converting them to H.264, as opposed to just keeping the VOB files as they are.

lol rented DVDs…you know the internet has this cool thing that lets you download pretty much anything you want for free right?
[/quote]
Yeah, but I have a 30GB download limit (and 30GB offpeak I guess) and a younger brother who has a cry every time I want to do anything while he’s playing games.[/quote]

It took us a full month to find an ISP that would even give us internet, and we still get 200GB…

Read full topic

item.title: Build questions
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

i did whole disk AES with truecrypt on a 1.7ghz celeron - youd be surprised how non impacting it is

though i guess the cpu will be nice if you need to do something disk heavy

Read full topic

item.title: Build questions
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

well if the processor is an oem version you’ll need to buy a heatsink, only the retail version comes with the stock heatsink

(the logo they use is the oem version but that could just be a mistake)

Read full topic

item.title: Build questions
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

@Niall: Uhh, I didn’t even look into things like the heatsink that it comes with. I hope there’s something packaged with it, because I’ve already placed my order. XD
The reason I got a good CPU is because I want to have software-based full disk encryption. I’m not too worried about playing the latest and greatest games, because every time I’ve been to a LAN party we’ve played older games anyway (Starcraft, AOE, Warcraft 3, CS:S, UT, etc).
I’m of the opinion that the price I paid for the RAM isn’t that bad.

I added that heatsink to my wishlist, but I’m going to hold off on buying it for now… I’d rather wait to see if I need anything else after I take the first delivery before ordering more, just so I can minimise delivery fees.

@Lawl: I actually read one of your posts about you having that PSU somewhere in another topic. Generally speaking, the Australian market always has higher prices than its US and UK counterparts, so some of the prices might seem inexplicably expensive.
Sometimes we get ripped off by price gougers, but more often than not it’s because the businesses have to pick a price and stick with it based on predictions of dollar value.

Read full topic

item.title: Build questions
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

Lothy:

For starters, I was reading the ‘post your build’ thread here and Niall’s Antec 900 was really dusty.

keep in mind the antec 900 has no filters and has a huge 200mm fan on top, plus I never clean the thing out

question: why such a high powered cpu and such a bad graphics card? if you want to save $100 you can get an i5 2500k instead, even at stock speeds it’s an incredibly powerful processor but if you compare it to an i7 2600k both overclocked to a similar speed they are very close

ps on your list the processor you got has the oem icon meaning it won’t come with the stock heatsink, is this intentional?

pps the noctua nh-d14 is a little expensive but it’s probably the best heatink you can buy, you can easily oc a i5 2500k or an i7 2600k to 4.7-5ghz speeds and get decent temperatures

ppps buy the cheapest ddr3 1600 ram you can, with sandybridge you don’t need good ram for overclocking

Read full topic

item.title: Build questions
item.dc:creator: @lawl lawl
item.description:
@lawl wrote:

Lothy, I have a corsair hx650 and its fucking excellent. You really cant go wrong with it. I got mine for $110 though.

Read full topic

item.title: Build questions
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

The filters that came with my case are brilliant. Hardly any visible dust in mine after nearly a year of having this case. I’d recommend trying to get filters too.

Read full topic

item.title: Build questions
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

At times like this I am glad I have access to a compressor.

Read full topic

item.title: Build questions
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

Those cans of compressed air cost at least $10 each here. I would prefer to clean filters rather than the inside of the entire case which has lots of nooks and crannies.

I’m not really interested in liquid cooling T4. Or rather I am from the ‘just because’ perspective (let’s face it, liquid cooling kits can look quite cool!) but the cost is prohibitive at the moment.
And even if I did use liquid cooling, the effectiveness of it would still largely depend on the air flow.

Read full topic

item.title: Build questions
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

Or you could use water/freon cooling?

Read full topic

item.title: Build questions
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

As to your question about dust, it really depends where you live. My parents live < 1 mile from a gravel pit, so everything gets dusty. As far as I know, I doubt there is any way you can prevent dust from getting in, even if you use filters, you will have to clean the dust from them regularly. I just prefer to use no filters and clean it out with compressed air (I use an air compressor, you could use a can if you want) every few months.

Read full topic

item.title: Build questions
item.dc:creator: @Baros_Rocks Baros Rocks
item.description:
@Baros_Rocks wrote:

I believe some of Corsair’s PSUs are made by Seasonic.

Read full topic

item.title: Build questions
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

A friend from university said Seasonic is good. I imagine that Corsair produces really good everything, but $200+ for a PSU seems a bit steep.

After taking a careful look at descriptions, I found a Corsair PSU that is modular to the same extent as the Seasonic one. It’s 650w instead of 620w, but that’s as close as I can get: http://www.pccasegear.com/index.php?main_page=product_info&products_id=12918

Read full topic

item.title: Build questions
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“Lothy, post:11, topic:407430”][quote author=Speljohan link=topic=508716.msg3690824#msg3690824 date=1312116863]
With a cpu like that overclocking is just a waste of resources (lowering the lifespan of your CPU). It will be able to handle anything you throw at it anyway.
[/quote]
By how much would the lifespan be reduced? I’ve had my current desktop since 2006, and aside from being loud (bearings in the CPU fan I think) it runs just fine. It isn’t overclocked, but I imagine it could run for another 3 to 4 years if I really needed it to.

If I got 4 years out of an overclocked CPU then that would be good enough for me. The reason I’m primarily interested in overclocking though is because I plan to use software-based full disk encryption.
Hopefully overclocking it a little will offset some of the overhead of that.
Also, I just want to try it to be honest. It’s something that I haven’t done before.

And thanks for the insight Baros.

EDIT: How would this PSU go? It’s mostly modular, with essential cables being permanently attached: http://www.pccasegear.com/index.php?main_page=product_info&cPath=15_535&products_id=13567

EDIT2: Here is my modified build with all feedback taken into account:
[/quote]I haven’t heard of that PSU brand before, doesn’t mean it’s bad though. Personally i stick with acknowledged and well known brands like Corsair, Cooler Master and Antec.

Read full topic

item.title: Build questions
item.dc:creator: @Baros_Rocks Baros Rocks
item.description:
@Baros_Rocks wrote:

Lothy:

The 2600 can’t be overclocked? I don’t fully understand the process, but I chose the motherboard with overclocking in mind so it’s important that I get the CPU right as well.

The k processors have an unlocked multiplier which just makes overclocking a lot easier. IIRC Intel have made it difficult to overclock the non-k series, apart from the turbo boost they have.

Read full topic

item.title: Build questions
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

Radeon:

See the cooler master 690 II advanced. It’s cheaper and while I don’t know how it compares with your current choice, I got it and I’m extremely satisfied with it. Been about 6 months since I built and still no visible dust inside thanks to the dust filters. Also my 2600 doesn’t go above 30 degrees ever.

I am really liking that case. Thanks for the protip.

Budda:

I havent bothered checking that PSU, but make sure you get a modular one, makes cable management easy as tits.

What’s a modular PSU? Does it let you plug as many or as few power cables into it as you like, as opposed to the ones that I’m used to where they just have loads of cables coming out?

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Budda Budda
item.description:

I havent bothered checking that PSU, but make sure you get a modular one, makes cable management easy as tits.
